The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).

Joining the Elk (a web Mastodon client in alpha) is Quite Good, Actually bandwagon:
https://elk.zone

title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

They should have struggled *against* that, imo. The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. - Looking for remote, but can commute (Minneapolis/St. Paul, MN, USA)
- I'm a trans woman, so clear acceptance/queer coworkers are a huge plus

Entry level would be best, I don't have enough work experience for most places to look at me mid-level. DM for a resume or any questions, take a look at my site for some examples of things I do!
https://werefox.cafe :aliceheartblack:
#GetFediHired #HachyJobs

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

If you’re outraged about Adobe sending your pictures off their servers (you should be), please know other vendors do this too. That horse has already bolted.

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

@networkscience
@academicchatter
#networkscience #networks

title: Here’s why electric vehicles need EV-specific tires

last_post.content:
An idea, I never considered. EVs need different tires than ICE cars because

1. EVs are heavier due to batteries.

2. Tires need to be quieter because EVs have less engine noise to drown out their sound.

3. EVs accelerate faster requiring more traction.
https://arstechnica.com/cars/2022/12/heres-why-electric-vehicles-need-ev-specific-tires/

When electronics importer Cara Leon goes missing, private investigator Sam Mujrif is hired by her sister to investigate. Cara is 8 times taller than Sam, but evidence soon points to players much smaller than either of them.

As Sam and his cross-scale colleagues pursue the case, it becomes apparent that Cara’s disappearance is linked to technology with the potential to reshape their whole society, and radically alter the balance of power between the scales.

https://www.gregegan.net/SCALE/SCALE.html

title: How has the Universe changed since last year?

last_post.content:
How has the Universe changed since last year?

The Sun is lighter; the Earth's orbit and rotational period have changed; the Moon is farther away; more galaxies are visible; but fewer stars are reachable.

Profound cosmic changes occur with each new year!
https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/universe-changed-year/

Hi, I've just moved over to hcommons.social, so here's an #introduction. I work (and make things) at the nexus of digital culture, politics and technology. I'm Prof of Media at Coventry University, UK, where I direct the Centre for Postdigital Cultures. I research non-liberal & non-humanist forms of collaboration and knowledge commons, as well as questions of class, elitism & digital capitalism. I’ve been involved for a while in creating ‘norm-critical’ collaborative research contexts. In 1999 I started an online journal Culture Machine http://www.culturemachine.net/. In 2006 I co-founded the open access publishing house Open Humanities Press. OHP was then a founder member of the Radical Open Access Collective http://radicaloa.disruptivemedia.org.uk/. My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

title: Twitter whistleblower Zatko lands new job at a security consulting firm

last_post.content: Twitter whistleblower and infosec pioneer Mudge Zatko is now working at Rapid7. https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/01/04/mudge-finds-a-new-job/

@michael_nielsen Btw, I consider any type of axiomatic characterization in mathematics as a form of discovery fiction.

For example, Shannon entropy was characterized by Faddeev as the only continuous function from probability distributions to real numbers that satisfies a very natural chain rule.

This is a simple way to motivate the entropy. The well-known formula with a logarithm then pops out of it by itself.

I first learned about this from a nice paper by Leinster:
http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.06961

Is there anything different about the #FAIR principles for research software (#FAIR4RS, https://doi.org/10.15497/RDA00068) when working in an #HPC context?

I think the answer is no for findability and accessibility, but I'm less sure if this is true for interoperability and reusability.

title: JPSO used facial recognition technology to arrest a man. The tech was wrong.

last_post.content:
Another Black man falsely accused of a crime and arrested because of a bad facial recognition search. Fourth or so we know about; probably many more we don't. title: ‘Disruptive’ science has declined — and no one knows why

last_post.content:
RT @maxdkozlov@twitter.com

'Disruptive' science has plummeted — and no one knows why.

Research in the 2000s is much more likely to incrementally push science forward than to veer off in a new direction.

Check out my latest for @Nature@twitter.com with @russellfunk@twitter.com, @dashunwang@twitter.com, @yian_yin@twitter.com

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04577-5

Won’t this cause a run on exchanges?

"This modest box is one of the first electronic voting machines in the history of the Congress. Electronic voting was introduced in the House in 1973. Members voted by inserting their voting card into the slot and pressing the appropriate button to indicate 'yea,' 'nay,' or 'present.' The stations also have an 'open' indicator, which is lit when a vote is in progress and the system is ready to accept votes."² #govtech (I never found any info on this IC chip.)

² https://history.house.gov/Collection/Detail/42898

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

title: Facial Recognition Tech Used To Jail Black Man For Louisiana Theft - He's Never Been To Louisiana

last_post.content:
Depressing that it was 5 years ago we wrote Gendershades (http://gendershades.org/) showing disparities & write:

"an error in the output of a face recognition algorithm used as input for other tasks can have serious consequences. For example, someone could
be wrongfully accused of a crime based on erroneous but confident misidentification of the perpetrator from security video footage analysis."

And here we are. And this is not the first case, nor will it be the last.

https://peopleofcolorintech.com/articles/facial-recognition-tech-used-to-jail-black-man-for-louisiana-theft-hes-never-been-to-louisiana/

title: Slack's private GitHub code repositories stolen over holidays

last_post.content:
Some of Slack's private GitHub code repos stolen over the holidays. It appears Slack often likes to use "noindex" to hide security disclosures.

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/slacks-private-github-code-repositories-stolen-over-holidays/

@futurebird
1) it uses the search API, so it should follow the same rules. A very vague test just now trying to search for a user and post on an instance our server is defederated from says it shouldn't work, but i'll have to double check and write tests for if an account has blocked someone. good question. had been on my mind and part of the reason why I haven't tried to pull upstream yet

2) It likely will be in the list of peer servers, but I don't know that masto uses this in any meaningful way, another thing i should check out

3) yes, unfortunately, this is something that would require the instance admin to apply

4) I tried to write something like this just using clientside javascript for eg. a bookmarklet, but the CORS rules prevented me from making the fetch to the OP server. I believe a browser extension would be able to overcome that problem, and it also looks like the search API doesn't require login (which seems bad actually) and so it might not even need to have you approve it with eg. OAuth or something like that. I have only written one extremely simple browser extension before, but this is ultimately extremely simple, basically this (and then refresh the page):

fetch(<other_instance>/api/<context_endpoint>
).then( (response) => {
response.json().descendants
.forEach( (status) => {
fetch(<search_api>/<status.url>);
}
});

in pseudo-javascript
https://github.com/NeuromatchAcademy/mastodon/blob/a209c1b0b43760a3915263d3e57c8140f0849acd/app/javascript/flavours/glitch/actions/statuses.js#L230-L257

Obesity is the last frontier in health issues where we ask people to make lifestyle changes versus medical intervention.

Everything else from depression to erectile dysfunction which people had to just deal with has drugs. We’re almost there for being fat

While ChatGPT is all the rage these days, as you may know it doesn't optimize for accuracy, but rather something like plausability.

I would thus like to highlight an alternative that only answers based on scientific papers, and does so while referencing all the sources:

https://elicit.org

To me, this is pretty awesome! Let's encourage this type of projects that promote accuracy and transparency of its sources!
